#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Loch Ness
#Text=Loch Ness is a lake or loch which runs for 23 miles ( 37 km ) along the fault line of the Great Glen in the Scottish Highlands .
#Text=It 's about a mile wide , very deep ( 740 ft / 226 m ) , and dark with peat .
#Text=It contains more fresh water than all the lakes , reservoirs and rivers of England and Wales combined , and is the supposed home of the Loch Ness Monster .
#Text=The Great Glen is the deep diagonal fault line that runs across Scotland from Fort William in the south-west to Inverness in the north-east .
#Text=The fault continues out to sea on both sides , as far as Shetland to the north and Clew Bay in Ireland to the west .
#Text=It formed some 430 million years ago as the Caledonian mountains were thrust up , and remains active to this day .
#Text=The fault movement shattered the granite , so that glaciers in later ice ages carved out a deep valley , which filled with rivers and lakes when the ice melted .
#Text=Loch Ness is the longest and deepest of these , with Loch Oich and Loch Lochy further south .
#Text=At its north end , Loch Ness is pinched into a narrow channel then widens again : this last section is called Loch Dochfour but it 's the same body of water .
#Text=The Glen has long been a transport route through the Highlands .
#Text=The first paved road was built by General Wade in the 1720s as a military route to keep the rebellious Highlanders in check .
#Text=Nowadays this is the B862 & B852 running along the unpopulated east bank of Loch Ness .
#Text=The modern main road is the A82 , which runs along the west bank .
#Text=The two roads combined make for a 70 mile ( 110 km ) circuit of the loch .
#Text=The Caledonian Canal is a coast-to-coast channel , built by Thomas Telford in the early 19th C , that makes use of the string of lochs and rivers along the glen .

#Text=Commercially and strategically it was obsolete as soon as it was completed in 1822 , as shipping had outgrown it , and round-the-coast navigation was much safer since the end of the Napoleonic wars .
#Text=It fell into disrepair but was rehabilitated for pleasure craft .
#Text=Loch Ness , its centrepiece , is the magnificent natural channel that does n't need maintenance , but there are ladders of lock-gates at each end that very much do .

#Text=At the south end the canal and River Oich feed in from Loch Oich , the highest part of the system ; at the north end , canal and River Ness flow down from Dochgarroch Weir towards the sea at Inverness .
#Text=Cities , Towns and Villages
#Text=See the entries below for details of transport , accommodation , eating & drinking , and sights & activities .
#Text=This page is just about the loch itself .
#Text=is six miles north of the loch .
#Text=It 's by far the largest town in the region , with the most visitor amenities , so it 's the obvious base for touring the loch and Great Glen .
#Text=It 's also close to other sights such as Culloden , the Black Isle , Aviemore , Spey Valley and Cairngorms National Park .
#Text=Along the east bank , via B852 & B862 the old military road , Dores is close enough to town to be commuterland , and has a couple of B&Bs and a pub , described under Inverness .
#Text=There 's basically nothing but scenery along the rest of the route , south through Inverfarigaig , Foyers and Whitebridge .
#Text=is a small village on the A82 ( west bank ) but with hotels and facilities out of proportion to its size , thanks to " monster " tourism .
#Text=The ruins of Urquhart Castle are two miles south at Strone point .
#Text=The A831 branches west here into wild lonely hills towards Glen Affric and Cannich village , eventually looping north back towards Inverness .
#Text=is an even smaller west-bank village where the River Moriston flows out into Loch Ness over a series of rapids .
#Text=There 's a couple of B&Bs and a camping & caravan site just south , and Alltsigh youth hostel two miles north , described under Fort Augustus .
#Text=The A887 branches west up scenic Glenmoriston , eventually joining A87 to Kyle of Lochalsh and Skye .
#Text=is the village at the south end of the loch , where the canal begins its final climb up to Loch Oich .
#Text=The fort , built in the 1730s , has variously been an abbey , a school , and a heritage centre , but is now an upmarket hotel .
#Text=is 20 miles south of the loch , where the Great Glen enters the sea .
#Text=So it 's not the standard base for visitors but it has good transport and amenities , and is close to Ben Nevis , Glencoe , and routes to the Hebrides .
#Text=With a car you can easily day-trip around Loch Ness from here .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Inverness Airport ( INV ) is 9 miles east of Inverness , off the A96 towards Nairn and Aberdeen .

#Text=It has flights to Amsterdam , London ( LHR , LGW and LTN ) , Bristol , Birmingham , Manchester , Kirkwall ( Orkney ) , Sumburgh ( Shetland ) , Benbecula ( for N & S Uist ) and Stornoway ( Lewis ) .
#Text=Glasgow GLA and Edinburgh EDI have a better choice of flights across Europe , then it 's a 3-hour drive north to reach the loch .
#Text=By train

#Text=Inverness has trains from Edinburgh , Glasgow , Perth , Aberdeen , London ( Kings Cross daytime , Euston for the Caledonian Sleeper ) , Kyle of Lochalsh for Skye , Ullapool for Stornoway on Lewis , and Thurso for Orkney .
#Text=Fort William has trains from Glasgow , and another portion of the Caledonian Sleeper from London Euston .
#Text=These trains also stop at Spean Bridge in the Great Glen , and various middle-of-nowhere places up the Spean valley and across desolate Rannoch Moor .
#Text=( You half-expect to see a Victorian ghillie in horse & trap awaiting , and the station for Brigadoon . )
#Text=Fort William also has trains to Glenfinnan and Mallaig , for Skye and the Small Isles .
#Text=There is no railway along Loch Ness .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Inverness has buses every hour or so from Edinburgh and Glasgow via Perth and Aviemore .
#Text=The main operators are Citylink , Parks of Hamilton and Megabus .
#Text=There 's an occasional through-bus from London Victoria .
#Text=Fort William has buses from Glasgow , Oban and Skye , plus summer services from Edinburgh , Perth , Kingussie and Aviemore .
#Text=Fort William and Inverness are linked by Citylink / Stagecoach Bus 919 , four times M-Sat and two on Sundays .
#Text=This runs along A82 via Spean Bridge , Laggan , Fort Augustus , Invermoriston and Drumnadrochit .
#Text=It 's a shared service , but each company only lists its own services , and there 's no combined ticketing .
#Text=This is no barrier to corporate guff about community transport partnerships .
